contents.content: News Corp, the media company controlled by Australian billionaire Rupert Murdoch, is eyeing a move into the video games market.

results.title: News Corp eyes video games market

contents.content: Yahoo has reached the grand old age of 10 and, in internet years, that is a long time. For many, Yahoo remains synonymous with the internet - a veteran that managed to ride the dot-com wave and the subsequent crash and maintain itself as one of the web's top brands.
The game is theirs to lose and MSN is the only one that stands in the way of Yahoo's domination.
For Jupiter analyst Olivier Beauvillain, Yahoo's initial decision to put its investment on search on hold was an error.
Search technology is valuable but the next generation of search is going to be about premium content and the interface that users have to that content.
Yahoo is a canny combination of acquisitions such as that of Inktomi and Overture, and by avoiding direct involvement in either content creation or internet access.

results.title: News Corp reaches grand old age

contents.content: About 50,000 new products will be unleashed at the tech-fest, which is the largest yet.

results.title: CES features several more key speeches from major technology players

contents.content: Gaming is becoming more of a social thing and all of the social genres will use this rich communications.
Video games are proving almost as profitable as they are fun.
Nick Hazel, Yahoo's head of consumer services in the UK, thinks Yahoo's vision of becoming the ultimate gateway to the web will move increasing towards movies and television.
Allen Weiner, a research director at Gartner and someone who has followed Yahoo's progress since the early years.

results.title: Gartner says Google is not a threat

contents.content: The company is planning to provide a range of services beyond the desktop.
